example: I had a lot of fun at the museum but  in a nutshell I saw lots of interesting things and learned a lot.
meaning: make the long story short or to make it brief

example: It is a left-handed compliment to say to someone  you look great for someone your age. This sounds good at first but it also means that people your age do not look good.
meaning: praise or saying good things about someone but with a hidden insult

example: I saw a man running out of the shop with a bag and I jumped to the conclusion that he had stolen something but that was not the case.
meaning: to make a decision before you have all the facts

example: She decided to go for broke and start her own business.
meaning: to take a big risk even if it means to lose everything

example: If you keep spending all your money you will later go broke and struggle to pay your bills.
meaning: something that has already been decided or settled and cannot be changed

example: The new plan is just a proposal and it is not as cut and dried as people think.
meaning: to write a brief letter or message to someone

example: If I don't hear from her by next week I will drop her a line.
meaning: to hope for good luck

example: I will keep my fingers crossed that you pass your driving test tomorrow.
meaning: to make a quick sound by clicking your fingers together.

example: As soon as I snap my fingers, please stand up and say your name.
meaning: finding something easily when you need it

example: With the help of a good dictionary all the words you need are at your fingertips
Mustafa forgot to do his homework but he got off the hook because the teacher was absent
meaning: help someone to get out of a difficult situation

example: You pay for the food but the drinks are on the house.
meaning: something that is given free of charge

example: Ramla makes a killing from her new shares in the company.
meaning: to get a lot of money in a short time

idiom: kill two birds with one stone
example: Let us drop off the kids at school and stop by the grocery store on the way so that we can kill two birds with one stone.
meaning: to succeed in doing two things at the same time with one action

example: My uncle was one of a kind and I can never be like him.
meaning: not like any other in the world

example: Ahmed and Eman are finally tying the knot this Friday.
meaning: getting married

example: Local companies want to compete on a level playing field with foreign companies.
meaning: a fair situation in which everyone has an equal opportunity.

idiom: light at the end of the tunnel
example: After months of hard work there is finally light at the end of the tunnel.
meaning: to see signs of hope after a difficult situtaion

example: I cannot tell you anything about the meeting. My lips are sealed.
meaning: a promise to keep a secret and not share any information.

example: Like it or lump it, find another job if you don't like the offer.
meaning: take it or leave it, whether you like it or not

example: I am by no means an expert on this topic, but I can try to answer your question.
meaning: not at all or definitely not

example: My uncle lives in another country so I only get to see him once in a blue moon.
meaning: almost never

example: She often goes overboard when she gets angry.
meaning: go too far or to do too much

example: Thanks for helping us move to our new house. I owe you one.
meaning: I will do the same for you. You say it to someone who has done a favor for you.

example: The manager gave Bilal a pat on the back for finishing the project ahead of schedule.
meaning: to congratulate or give credit to someone for doing a great job

example: I really need a million to start a new business but I guess half a million would do in a pinch.
meaning: when it becomes necessary and you have no other choice

example: There are new projects in the pipeline that will be out next year.
meaning: something that is being planned or on the way

example: After years of working for other people, Asiya finally decided to take the plunge and start her own business.
meaning: to take a big risk or make a big decision after thinking about it for a long time

example: Before you sign a contract, it is better to read between the lines to make sure you understand all the terms.
meaning: try to understand the hidden meaning behind what someone is saying or writing

example: Many people complain about the amount of red tape they have to deal with when they are registering a new car.
meaning: so many rules and steps that delay and make things difficult to complete

example: As a last resort I decided to ask my parents for a loan to pay the rent and other expenses.
meaning: the final option available after all other options have been tried

example: I am so glad that our noisy neighbors have finally moved out. Good riddance!
meaning: a rude way of saying you are happy that someone or something is gone

example: I can't remember his face, but the name does ring a bell.
meaning: sounds familiar or reminds you of something but you cannot remember it clearly

example: Their marriage has been on the rocks for months now.
meaning: in trouble with lots of problems and will likely fail soon

example: As a rule of thumb, it is always a good idea to set aside a part of your income every month for emergencies.
meaning: practical guideline that is often based on expreience

example: After graduating from university, Sara decided to travel around the world on a shoestring budget.
meaning: limited budget like doing something with very little money

example: Before we start the meeting, let us stay on topic and not go off on a tangent.
meaning: to suddenly change the topic

example: My computer is up and running now.
meaning: operating or working normally

example: It is always good to have something up your sleeve in case things don't go as planned.
meaning: to have a secret plan or trick that you can use at the right time

example: A year ago he was against the idea but now he changed his tune and fully supports it.
meaning: to change your opinion or behavior

example: Losing my job was a blessing in disguise because it led me to start my own successful business.
meaning: something that seems bad or unlucky at first but becomes something good later.

example: My holiday plans are not set in stone yet, so we can change the date if needed.
meaning: unchangeable or something that cannot be changed

idiom: give someone the benefit of the doubt
example: She was late to the meeting, but I gave her the benefit of the doubt because she usually arrives on time.
meaning: to trust someone even though you are not sure what they say is true

example: I know you love movies but it is  really not my cup of tea.
meaning: not for me or something that someone is not interested in

example: Everyone seems happy with the decision so let us not rock the boat.
meaning: to cause problems when the situation is calm or working just fine

example: I am not the kind of person who jumps on the bandwagon but I rather like to make my own choices.
meaning: follow the crowd or  following something because it has become popular

example: I thought the test would be difficult but it was a piece of cake.
meaning: very easy to do

idiom: get a taste of your own medicine
example: After years of spreading fake information about her friends, she finally got a taste of her own medicine when her best friend gossiped about her.
meaning: to treat someone as badly as they have treated you or to get a dose of your own medicine

example: She has been feeling under the weather since yesterday so she is resting at home.
meaning: sick or not feeling well

example: Your name rings a bell  but I can't remember where we met.
meaning: sounds familiar or reminds me of something

example: During the dinner, the fact that Sarah had not been invited became the elephant in the room.
meaning: an important problem or issue that people avoid talking about

idiom: the devil is in the details
example: They agreed on the deal quickly but the devil is in the details and negotiating the contract took weeks.
meaning: the smallest parts of a work or the small details that are often the most difficult

example: During the presentation she covered the whole nine yards leaving no question unanswered.
meaning: do everything that is possible or the whole thing

example: Maria  asked for a quick meeting to tie up loose ends before the weekend.
meaning: to finalize or complete the final parts of work

example: When the project faced difficulties, we saw his true colors as a leader.
meaning: To show what you are really like or your real character

idiom: bite off more than I can chew
example: He bit off more than he could chew by registering too many advanced classes this term.
meaning: to try to do too much or  take on more responsibility than you can really do

example: Hiring someone without a proper background check could be a wild card because you never know what problems they might bring.
meaning: unpredictable like someone or a situation that is difficult to guess

idiom: get back to the drawing board
example: If this solution doesn't fix the problem, we'll have to get back to the drawing board.
meaning: to start planning again or to begin again

example: If you cut corners on the project, the final product may not meet the standards.
meaning: to take shortcuts or do something in the quickest and cheapest way

idiom: cross that bridge when we get to it
example: I am not sure how we will pay the bills if you leave your job but let us cross that bridge when we get to it.
meaning: to deal with a problem only when it happens not before

example: She was excited to receive the job offer and the generous benefits package was the icing on the cake.
meaning: an extra good thing added to an already good situation.

example: A fun game is a great way to break the ice at a meeting and get people talking to each other.
meaning: to do or say something that helps people who are meeting for the first time feel more relaxed and comfortable with each other.

idiom: hit the nail on the head
example: When she said the project failed due to poor communication, she really hit the nail on the head.
meaning: to be exactly right about something

idiom: take something with a grain of salt
example: When reading online reviews, it's wise to take them with a grain of salt.
meaning: not to fully believe something

idiom: between a rock and a hard place
example: He is caught between a rock and a hard place because he needs to choose between taking a lower-paying job and moving to a different city.
meaning: to be in a very difficult situation where you have to make a tough decision.

example: She gave me a backhanded compliment by saying my dress was nice for someone my age.
meaning: Something that someone says to you but has a hidden criticism.

idiom: every cloud has a silver lining
example: When I missed my flight, I reminded myself that every cloud has a silver lining, so I had a chance to explore a new city.
meaning: There is something good in every bad situation.

example: It is getting late, so let us call it a day and continue tomorrow.
meaning: Let us stop working for the day.

example: It is not helpful to point fingers when things go wrong; we need to find a solution.
meaning: to accuse or blame someone

example: She didn't want to know about the world's troubles, so she avoided the news. As they say, "ignorance is bliss."
meaning: sometimes it is better not knowing about a problem because knowing about it can cause worry or unhappiness

example: We will leave no stone unturned to find the missing child.
meaning: to  try everything possible or do everything you can to find something or solve a problem.

idiom: let the cat out of the bag
example: Try not to let the cat out of the bag until the announcement is official
meaning: to tell someone a secret often by mistake

example: You'll miss the boat if you don't buy shares now because the opportunity to invest at this price won't last long.
meaning: to miss an opportunity because you are too slow or do not act in time.

example: He enjoys the best of both worlds by working part-time and studying.
meaning: to have the benefits of two different things at the same time.

example: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you really think.
meaning: to avoid saying something directly.

idiom: can't have your cake and eat it too
example: You want to save money but also go on vacation, but you can’t have your cake and eat it too.
meaning: You cannot have both so you have to make a choice

example: I can’t believe you spilled the beans about our plan.
meaning: to tell a secret

example: My sister and I don’t always see eye to eye on everything.
meaning: completely agree or be on the same page about something

idiom: save something for a rainy day
example: I always try to save a little money for a rainy day.
meaning: to save or reserve something for future use when it is needed most.

example: This new evidence sheds light on what really happened.
meaning: to explain or make something easier to understand

example: Speak of the devil! I was just saying your name.
meaning: used when someone you were talking about comes

example: If you’re ever in my neck of the woods, let me know.
meaning: an area or neighborhood

example: I need time to wrap my head around all this information.
meaning: to find a way to understand something difficult

example: The future of the project is up in the air until we get funding from our donor.
meaning: undecided like when no decision has been made

idiom: judge a book by its cover
example: Don’t judge a book by its cover because she may look quiet, but she is very talented.
meaning: to evaluate or form an opinion on how something looks

example: The manager knows about it, but he decided to turn a blind eye.
meaning: to ignore something on purpose

idiom: have got it in the bag
example: The team is so far ahead, so they have got the game in the bag.
meaning: something is guaranteed like when you are sure about the success of something

example: I thought he was my friend, but when he shared my secret it felt like a stab in the back.
meaning: when a friend or someone you trusted betrays or harms you

example: I tried to stay patient but his rude comment was the last straw, and I couldn’t take it anymore.
meaning: the final bad thing that happens causing you to give up or get really angry

example: Life can be difficult but if you hang in there, you will find your way.
meaning: to stay strong when you are in a difficult situation

idiom: in the twinkling of an eye
example: She answered the question in the twinkling of an eye.
meaning: happens very fast or so quickly

example: The scientists believe they are on the right track even though the research is still ongoing.
meaning: going in the right direction or  making progress

example: Many believe the president has been feathering his nest instead of serving the people.
meaning: to make money for your own selfish interests

example: The project ran into difficulties when the funding was cut off.
meaning: to face problems often without expecting it

idiom: the proof is in the pudding
example: The app looks great but the proof is in the pudding when customers start using it.
meaning: you only know by trying or the results show the truth
